content:
I saw the variable name "motive" is used for something specifying "any predicate", but I didn't see "motive" wording before ever.
NOTE: I'm privately learning logic sometimes just as hobby (and mainly in Japanese)

Is there any scenes behind it? Thanks!
It's just the word the computer scientists use for "the thing you're trying to prove by induction"
Luma has marked this topic as resolved.
I could find some "motive" usage in CIC related contexts.
I'm still curious how that naming was motivated!

It seems like the kind of slightly-colorful naming you would expect from a paper by Conor McBride, but it makes some sense, the induction hypothesis is "why you are doing the induction" so 'motive' looks like an appropriate term

Oh, one of these I found is written by him.
The title is "Elimination with a Motive" which includes "motive"
https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/3-540-45842-5_13
